ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Writing poetry regularly, when you read your poems you publish your words into the air, read slower, be obsessed, something is better than nothing
Gained general practice on writing poems, as well as analyzing poetry. Also received one on one feedback from the professor, which was very helpful and thoughtfully given.

This course drilled pretty rudimentary poetry writing concepts I was familiar with (e.g. form serves function and vice versa, show not tell) and some cool new concepts e.g. genre is a myth). I also learned more about creating a collection or book that is about one subject and how to better embody in your poetry the research and history you are writing about.
Reading and writing poems, historical exploration, archival resources
How to write a crown of sonnets, how to structure poetic writing grounded in historical subjects.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: prof jess has so much experience, humor, connections to amazing guests, and just good stories; writing a poem almost every week feels like both a lot and also not too heavy, we stopped doing as many readings and focused more on writing Weaknesses: communication with the professor can be challenging at times, need to be willing to flow with it,  he isn't mean about your writing but hes also not going to hype you up or give you excessive feedback. I did find most of his feedback useful!

Weaknesses: almost no structure, low communication on assignments or grade expectations, etc. However, it was an exceedingly delightful class and gave us the freedom to practice poetic thinking / writing without strain.

Weaknesses: Professor Jess is incredibly unorganized. He did not have a Canvas for the class until the 4th week of the semester, and it was clear that he did not know how to use Canvas or take the time to learn it. I also did not feel challenged by the class content or assignments, so I felt like a grew very little, if at all, in my poetry writing this semester, which is so disappointing and makes me wish I took a different class. Jess also provides little feedback on assignments (you really have to hound him for it) and is poor at email communication. He also did not try hard at all to learn any students name, and by the end of the semester, he could only name 3/11 of us correctly.

Strengths: As a Pulitzer winner and amazing poet, Jess sometimes gives good advice on writing and research. He also knows other major writers and organizations, so we had a few guest speakers come in throughout the semester. Lastly, Professor Jess is so unorganized that there ended up being barely any work assigned during the last half of the semester, so the class was easy.

This was overall an amazing class. I was at times confused about the expectations/the assignments because they seemed to differ from the syllabus, but I learned so much from my classmates and Prof. Jess.
This course could benefit from more structure/fidelity to the reading schedule on the syllabus. As well as a more structured approach to in class feedback for student's poems.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yale does not currently have many poetry professors it feels. If you're someone who stresses out a lot about deadlines and not having information and not being able to contact the professor, maybe don't take it. But the opportunity to work with this professor in this class environment is quite unique and unlike many creative writing classes at Yale and you really feel like a writer
Yes, if you are ready to write!
Unfortunately, no. It is an easy class and A, but if you want to grow and be challenged as a writer, you will be severely disappointed. Look elsewhere!
